Description: The FCC's Enforcement Bureau reached a $16 million settlement with CenturyLink and a $1.4 million settlement with Intrado Communications related to the companies' failures to meet their emergency call obligations during a 2014 multi-state 911 outage.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division

The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: The Federal Communications Commission entered into a Consent Decree with Qwest Communications International, Inc. in which Qwest admitted that it violated a federal ban on providing long distance services in its local service region prior to receiving FCC authorization.

Qwest Communications International Inc. agreed to pay $250 million to settle allegations of securities fraud. The SEC had alleged that, between 1999 and 2002, Qwest fraudulently recognized over $3.8 billion in revenue and excluded $231 million in expenses as part of a multi-faceted fraudulent scheme to meet optimistic and unsupportable revenue and earnings projections.
national origin
Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Description: overtime violation
overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Brennan et al v. Qwest Communications International, Inc. et al
Walter v. Level 3 Communications, Inc. et al
Stuhr v. Qwest Comm Intl Inc, et al

Description: Level 3 agreed to pay more than $8 million to resolve allegations it improperly withheld rental payments that it owed to Massachusetts under an agreement allowing it to run fiber optic cables alongside state highways.
Qwest paid $19 million to settle state allegations that it engaged in a number of fraudulent accounting practices that had the impact of falsely inflating the value of Qwest securities.

Qwest agreed to pay $3.75 million and an unspecified amount in restitution in settlement of allegations of violations of consumer protection laws by misrepresenting services and charges, cramming phone bills and other unauthorized charges.
Qwest agreed to pay $1 million in damages and fees, plus restitution, in settlement of allegations its marketing of telephone services was deceptive.
slamming/cramming violations
charging for unwanted services

Company: Qwest Communications Corp. and LCI International Telecom Corp.
Description: Qwest Communications Corporation and LCI International Telecom Corporation agreed to pay restitution and $350,000 to the state in settlement of allegations their marketing of long distance telephone services was deceptive and they switched consumers' long distance telephone service without proper authorization.
unauthorized switching of a customer's long-distance servive

Info Source: Qwest to Pay $350,000 Settlement, Associated Press, April 27, 2001 (via Nexis).

Description: slamming case
Info Source: Company settles Complaints with Attorney General, Associated Press, June 1, 2000 (via Nexis).

Description: Qwest agreed to pay $1.1 million in settlement of allegations it switched customers' telephone service carriers without authorization, billed for services not provided, and billed former customers.
Qwest agreed to pay refunds plus $200,000 to the state in settlement of allegations of unauthorized charges on telephone bills, misrepresentation of services and undisclosed charges.
cramming violations
slamming and cramming
911 outage
slamming violation
Agency: New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs
Info Source: Qwest to Pay N.J. Regulators $500,000 in Slamming Case, The Record (Bergen, NJ), April 18, 2001 (via Nexis).

Description: deceptive advertising and billing practices

Info Source: Extracted from a spreadsheet obtained from the NLRB through a Freedom of Information Act request fulfilled on 5/28/2020.

Description: 911 outage
Air Quality Act
Info Source: Contained in a spreadsheet obtained from the agency on October 7, 2020 in response to an open records request. The spreadsheet contains cases from the enforcement database accessible at https://enfo.gaepd.org/Orders/Search

Description: storage tank violation
water pollution violation
The Commission fined USLD Communications, a subsidiary of Denver-based Qwest Communications, $1 million for overcharging consumers making operator-assisted calls from pay phones.
Info Source: Utility fined $1 million for pay-phone overcharging, Seattle Times, April 13, 2000 (via Nexis).

Description: The Washington Utilities and Transportation Commission ordered Qwest to pay a total of $ 3.2 million for not living up to service levels established as a condition of its merger with U S West in 2000.
Info Source: QWEST FINED $3.2 MILLION BY REGULATORS, The Columbian, March 15, 2002 (via Nexis).

Description: CenturyLink Inc., now known as Lumen Technologies Inc., has agreed to pay $275,000 to resolve a civil contempt claim by the Department of Justice arising from CenturyLink's violations of the Amended Final Judgment that was designed to preserve competition following CenturyLink's 2018 acquisition of Level 3 Communications Inc.

Level 3 Communications, LLC agreed to pay $12,772,843 to settle allegations involving: kickbacks paid to former Level 3 officials in return for favorable treatment to subcontractors in connection with government contracts; improperly obtaining competitive bid information; and misstating compliance with woman-owned small business subcontracting requirements.

The Washington Utilities and Transportation Commission assessed a $7.8 million penalty against Qwest Corporation on Feb. 28, 2005, for failing to file interconnection contracts with rival carriers who use Qwest's phone network. The UTC said that the company violated federal and state laws by withholding the contracts from public review.
Info Source: QWEST PENALIZED $7.8 MILLION FOR FAILING TO FILE CONTRACTS WITH COMPETITORS, US States News, January 12, 2006 (via Nexis).

Description: The Commission fined CenturyLink $2.85 million for a six-hour, statewide 911 outage in 2014.

The New Mexico Public Regulation Commission ordered the Denver-based telecommunication company to pay a $2 million fine to the state and $1.5 million to five telecommunication companies for failing to abide by state and federal regulations.
Info Source: Qwest to pay $3.5 million, Albuquerque Tribune, July 1, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: The North Dakota Public Service Commission approved an agreement that required CenturyLink to improve phone service to some western North Dakota communities and included a commitment of $2.66 million in infrastructure improvements. The order came after the Commission filed a formal complaint against the company for a series of complaints related to service.
An appeals court upheld a $25.9 million fine against Qwest, Minnesota's dominant phone company, for cutting secret deals with competitors.
Info Source: Appeals court upholds $25.9 million fine against Qwest, Associated Press, November 1, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: The commission fined Qwest $900,000 in 2002 for trying to delay AT&T in offering local phone service in Minnesota. In 2006 the PUC reduced the fine to $360,000 -- in part because AT&T eventually decided not to compete against Qwest.
Info Source: PUC upholds Qwest fine of $26M, St. Paul Pioneer Press, June 28, 2006 (via Nexis).

Description: violation of 911 rules

This decision finds that Qwest and LCI violated PU Code Sections 2889.5 and 2890, as well as other statutes, in the course of their marketing activities, and that sanctions are warranted for these violations. Qwest failed to adequately supervise its sales agents so that the agents switched thousands of customers' long distance telephone service without their permission. In some cases, the third-party verification tapes or letters of authorization confirming the switches were falsified. Qwest also placed unauthorized charges on thousands of customers' telephone bills.

In this decision, the Commission approved the settlement agreement between Qwest and CPSD concerning compliance with statutes, decisions, and other requirements applicable to the utility's installation of facilities in California for providing telecommunications service.  Under the settlement agreement, Qwest agreed to pay $150,000 to the State's General Fund and to contribute $30,000 to three groups that promote awareness of Native American sites, archaeology and history within California.

Info Source: US West fined $1.5 million for delays, complaints, Albuquerque Tribune, February 1, 2000 (via Nexis).

Description: Qwest Communications International was ordered to pay $20.7 million in fines and restitution for failing to report deals it made with some competitors.
Info Source: QWEST MUST PAY $20.7 MIL, Arizona Republic, April 22, 2004 (via Nexis).

Description: Interfered with Section 271 regulatory process
